Dark sorcery carves a rift into the air, creating a portal into the western reaches of the Old World.
Hulking machines of war mean little when the Changer's armies can step through a portal at a moment's notice.
Hulking machines of war mean little when the Changer's armies can step through a portal at a moment's notice.
Through the power of Tzeentch's malevolent sorcery, the southern tip of the Old World is always within reach.
Summon forth the magics of the Great Deceiver, instantly bridging the distance between the Changeling and the Land of Chill.
Once the rift opens, all of Ulthuan will tremble, for nothing can halt the armies of change pouring from its gaping maw.
Dark Magic converges into a fluctuating portal, providing an instant gateway to the lands of the east.
Dark Magic converges into a fluctuating portal, providing an instant gateway to the lands of the east.
With the jaws of fate wrenched open wide, the jungles of Lustria are more vulnerable than ever.
Every scheme begins with a seed, planted in plain sight of the Changeling's victims.
The unseen Mark of Tzeentch is inscribed upon every stone in every land, for this is His design. To those granted the Raven's sight, the bounties are great indeed.
Let dull metal become lustrous gold. For the Changer of Ways, this requires only a thought.
The puppeteering of space and time is accompanied by the acrid-sweet smell of burning reality, and the sense of something serpentine tunnelling through one's mind.
Whispering doubt. Hissing mistrust. Murmured envy. The Great Conspirator's dark will makes a mockery of allegiance, courage and friendship alike.
A kaleidoscope of blazing colour, hypnotic in its majesty. Before those engulfed by it are reduced to ashes, they will witness the truth.
Searing scarlet, blinding blue, glorious gold: these are the writhing colours of Tzeentch's uncanny balefire.
Tzeentch listens. Tzeentch sees. Tzeentch knows.
By fundamentally redesigning how field guns are constructed, we can maximise the firepower of each machine while saving resources in less important areas.
A minor member of the Imperial aristocracy he may be, but the Emperor's ambassador knows exactly what to say, and how to say it, to guarantee a favourable outcome to proceedings.
Grand Cathay is home to many wonders, many of which could be put to good use by the Empire.
Unintelligent though they are, one cannot deny the usefulness and power of having a mighty Ogre Tyrant on side.
Any who hold the ear of Countess Emmanuelle von Liebwitz enjoy boundless influence across all of Nuln.
By infusing Death Magic into the powerful arms of Nuln, new, ever-more deadly weapons are conceived.
Elspeth often spends time travelling between her Towers, in search of lost lore and artefacts of untold power.
Despite her reclusive nature, Elspeth is and forever will be a true child and defender of the Empire.
When not training in his magic or practising his Alchemy, Gelt can often be found in the College Archives studying his crafts.
Under the protection of and guidance of the Colleges of Magic, Wizards can hone their craft to the highest level.
The Priests atop the Luminark hone their chants and prayers, offering greater protection to those around them.
The height of Imperial Engineering; just having these machines on the battlefield rallies nearby troops to sweeping pride!
The Warden of the White Tower is known to many as the most powerful Wizard the mortal world has ever seen; fortunately, he imparts his wisdom gladly.
Long ago, Teclis founded the eight Colleges of Magic; ever since, human Wizards have gathered to learn and practise their craft.
The Supreme Patriarch protects and guides the Colleges, ensuring dangerous magics are kept tightly under control.
It is in the Hall of Duels that a new Patriarch is decided and each Wizard must prove their worth.
Always the first into battle on the charge, these elite troops aim for the very heart of the foe.
Braced for the onslaught, these extensively-drilled spearmen hold fast in the face of the enemy.
Those who dare approach Imperial battle lines must face multiple hails of arrows before the first blow is even struck.
These men's superior engineering skills are matched only by their martial prowess, as evidenced by the explosions that ring around the battlefield during the combat.
These advanced horsemen ensure that the enemy's numbers are fewer than intended when battle is finally joined.
Those who try to escape the fray will find their flanks blocked by noble steel, ranged against the foe in the Emperor's name.
Leadbelchers will fire whatever is at hand at the foe, even grabbing the nearest Gnoblar and sending them flying!
Whether it be cannonballs, scrap metal or even picking up the cannon itself and using it like a club, Leadbelchers pack a *serious* punch.
The Mournfang somehow find themselves ahead of the pack and ready to outflank the enemy. Was it careful planning or did they simply catch the aroma of a tasty meal?
While it's not unheard of, Ogres often don't eat their Gnoblar workers because they are "too stringy", a silver lining that puts most Gnoblars minds at ease.
Between battles, Gnoblars are hot on their feet doing whatever their masters demand of them, lest they are turned into dinner.
Be it by claw, talon or fang, the beasts of the Ogre Kingdoms tear through even the strongest of defences.
Compared to the cramped, torturous conditions of their beastpens, the battlefield, however savage, is a refreshing break for these creatures.
The unwanted cast-offs that have survived in the dark tunnels below the mountains have known nothing but hardship, but are all the stronger for it.
Ogres have learnt to keep their mostly uncontrollable beasts under control, even when moving between camp locations.
Living in the mountains, Giants often have to bat off falling debris or the attacks of wild beasts, toughening their skin and flesh as a result of the scarring.
To inflict maximum damage, Ogres might attach scrap metal, stone or even unsuspecting, live Gnoblars to a Giant's club.
Spiked plates attached to the tusks or horns of great beasts make their already deadly swing all the deadlier.
When the creatures that live atop the Mountains of Mourn come down into the valleys, they find their stamina levels increased in the thicker air, as if their restraints had been lifted.
When all is said and done, there's simply no place quite like home.
While some Ogres take their camps and travel across the world, others know every inch of their mountainous homelands and rarely leave their birthplace.
Claws and sword and flail stoke Khorne's fires. The true might of His inferno lies elsewhere. No wonder His Realm is nothing but churned and blasted earth.
Shot and arrow are but spittle in the face of Khorne's hordes. They return this slight with the flight of heavy axe and overwhelming bulk.
A Daemonically-imbued body's bone is the clockwork of war. The spray of blood, its ticking. An inhuman machine's onslaught, its final toll.
Khorne can return millennial rock to its primeval state of nothingness in the blink of an eye. From nothingness, He can also conjure armies and lend them a fraction of this power.
Mere mortals gain mastery of war in decades, but even mere footsoldiers of Khorne are created with it.
Khorne's fury can bend monstrosities to its will, to serve Him.  Those who remain as foes will be bent, then broken by the ones whom He has chosen for the task.
Swinging at a whirlwind is nothing a sane creature would do. Yet in battles against Khorne, sometimes the whirlwind is the one who swings.
Where Khorne slavers, monsters rise. Where He steps, their breeding pits take shape. Where He points, their hunting grounds are drawn.
Khorne's will strikes the earth as a hammer strikes an anvil. The sparks of fury spawned thereof possess a terrifying tenacity.
As Khorne's will manifests in the mortal realm, the Winds of Magic twist themselves in horn and brass, already in full flight.
A wasteland's snow or sand at rest cannot compare to dust forever ground into primeval matter by relentless wrath. That is the mark of Khorne's true domain.
That which only grows under His care is towering pyres, fulminating wastes and blood-fed hordes. No more.
A bloody pact with Khorne shall gain his favour.
Once earnt, Nurgle will be even keener for the Dark Master to spread his gifts.
Earn Tzeentch's favour and a further fractal of his power.
Learn the last secret and earn Slaanesh's trust.
Take from them their iron fist and make it your own!
Let us claim the secrets of the well-oiled machine of industry for our own, the Chaos Dwarfs won’t be needing it anymore…
Let them build their Bastion; let them muster their pampered peoples. In time, all shall be rubble and corpses.
Let them feel the hammer not on anvil, but on flesh. Let the molten industry be consumed by flame!
So fat and satisfied – their dedication to the Great Maw blinds them from the truth marching to their mawstep.
From high peaks to valley depths cradles knowledge foreign to our own – but tried and useful nonetheless.
Scorched wastelands, winding rivers and a great toothed wound in the earth lie beyond the old Dwarfholds.
They merely adopted the cold – we were born in it, molded by it.
Let nothing remain of us but the ice in our hearts.
Fair Aquitaine: a land of rolling fields, sandy shores... and incessant noble feuds.
Cathayan horses are no less flighty than their otherwise inferior Old World kin, but an expert rider knows that bestowing stillness upon their anxious steed is paramount to victory.
The Dragon Emperor's Celestial hand shall ease our path, no matter what might assail us on the way. All we need do is look for His radiance, and follow after it.
A drying process, taught by an Ogre Butcher outcast from his tribe due to too many vegetable-based recipes, strengthens peasants' makeshift armour without rendering it brittle.
It is said that each stone sentinel sings a constant and divine song of purification, sadly inaudible to all those not born of Dragon-blood.
The House of Secrets refuses to disclose quite which reagents have been added to the mixture, but there is no denying that it builds sturdy structures at minimal cost.
Every soul in the Celestial Empire, no matter how low-born, is deserving of the Dragon Emperor's care. It falls to Yuan Bo, the Jade Dragon, to share His purse amongst the commonfolk.
Because the Moon Empress blesses every arrow in the Celestial Empire, it is contingent upon our fletchers to construct them with the utmost care, and our archers to not waste even a single shot.
As the moon's silver light washes over us, Quai Yin shall grant Her blessing. Darkness shall hone our blades, and shadows shall form our armour.

The Dragon Emperor has seen countless species rise and fall, and can teach us much of them. The ancient Chelonian turtles possessed nigh-unbreakable shells – this, we can recreate with wood and steel.
Strike fast, strike hard, no mercy is a fine mantra, but futile should the enemy feel similarly. Defence is of equal import, and uncannily lightweight alchemical steel shall provide it.
Patience, planning and practice: obey these tenets always, and we shall move as the night wind – silent, graceful and unimpeded by any obstacle.
The school of Feng Shi sorcery, named for the Dragon Emperor himself, grants strength and protection to all those who wield it. It is the highest honour to march beneath the Yang banner.
True balance requires the trust and participation of all souls. Only when we think and work as one will absolute harmony of purpose be achieved.
The Moon Empress shall bind our foes in tendrils of night, and in balance her kiss shall grant our bows new strength.
The Moon Empress loves every child of Cathay dearly, but she most favours those who show fealty to the elemental winds of shadow and spirit.
Absolute discipline. Perfect alignment of purpose. Every soldier knowing their place. This is the Harmony of Stone and Steel.
It is the Jade Warriors who keep the great cities of Cathay safe, but they are too gracious to demand promotion. Thus, we must identify and raise up their finest ourselves.
It takes time for a newly-awakened Sentinel to regain its full might, as it sheds the moss and earth of years, but the correct incantations will instantly purge all such detritus.
Yang is the strength of the soul. Yang is the flame in the heart and the fire in our veins. Yang is the roar from the lungs. Yang is the iron within our bones and the stone beneath our skins.
The Dragon Emperor's Celestial fire burns hotter than all else. Bricks baked in the Burning Wind emerge strong and flawless, all the better to build great monuments to Xen Yang.
The Celestial Dragon will raise us all up – we need only to heed His wisdom. And so, by tapping the flame within their souls, the Dragon Emperor's soldiers shall become tireless.
So well-drilled are the Jade Lancers of Cathay, and so fluid their steeds, that they could outflank their enemy even within the narrowest of alleyways.
As majestic as jade, as unbreakable as stone: this what every devoted warrior of Cathay, whether born to power or peasantry, must eternally strive to be.
All the world envies Cathay's most grandiose technologies, but it is in the smallest of things, such as cogwheels no larger than a hummingbird's eye, that we truly innovate.
So numerous are the warriors of wind and field that it is impossible to keep a tally of the wounded, but learned physicians can at least identify the most grievously harmed.
If the great magnets within a War Compass are suddenly inverted, they will repulse incoming fusillades, scattering missiles like blossom on the breeze.
There are those who obtain status through ignoble means, and there are those who debase their heraldry. Fortunately, true Dragon-blooded may replace them at a whim.
By putting ego to one side and working together, there is no limit to the innovations the outcast Sorcerers of the House of Secrets might devise.
The people cannot protest against the Jade Dragon's law if they are paid in the Jade Dragon's coin.
Yin-Yin rules over the Jade Sea and far beyond, and it is she who keeps Cathay's ports safe from crime and corruption. Only by the Sea Dragon's grace is fresh trade allowed or disallowed.
The great inventions of the City of Smoke generate more wealth than most other empires put together. We are fortunate indeed that it shares its technologies with us.
The grand artificers of Cathay's impregnable heart of industry are capable of creating weapons reputedly as everlasting as the Great Bastion itself.
What the warriors of wind and field might lack in formal training they make up for with the wily skills of born hunters.
Down to the lowliest middle-managers, every servant of the Emperor must work towards the common goals of good fortune and prosperity for every Cathayan soul.
The cloak of darkness is merely a state of mind to which only a few are attuned, enabling them to move unseen and unheard even in the broadest daylight.
Our legion can learn to draw from within themselves an invisible miasma of the Moon Empress' enduring love, which as it envelops our foes shall blunt their every strike.
Previously unseen beyond the Forests of the Moon, a pitch-black tree which yields lumber as tough as fresh-forged iron has spread to the slopes of Kunlan – no doubt with Quai Yin's blessing.
To drink of purest Yin energy, filtered from the silver waters of the Dragon River, is to become as swift and weightless as a spirit, unbound by corporeal convention.
The Ogre merchants of the Ivory Road charge a pretty penny to have their trained Giants stomp on our cannon wadding, but the compressed results can be loaded with incredible speed.
A criss-crossing of miniature blades within the gun barrel's interior scores hundreds of vicious edges into every piece of shot. Only Nan-Gau's most diligent artificers can achieve this feat.
A fresh edict: only those born to a family which has known no short-sightedness or blindness for five generations may wield a Jade crossbow. Even then, they must prove themselves.
The Moon Empress can take any form, and it is thanks to her time spent running with the herds, free as the wind, that we may now learn the language of horses.
Every Spirit Qilin yearns to return to the Celestial Mountains, and have been known to depart for them even in the heat of battle. Incanting a Yang rite upon their reins will ensure obedience.
The Dragon Emperor sees all, and so it is that an infusion of His Celestial magic can grant sight beyond sight to His most loyal believers.
Stillness of the mind and soul are virtues to which we all must aspire. Only with impeccable discipline and balance may we truly prevail against wickedness.
In public, all obey the Dragon Emperor without question, but in private many provinces vie for independence and power. Those who serve Him faithfully shall be rewarded.
Rare crystals litter the peaks of Kunlan, each of which absorbed a fragment of the Celestial energy unleashed by the Dragon Emperor's birth. Once socketed into an anvil, divine armour may be forged.
But a word from the Sea Dragon is all that is required to grant passage or permit. We may also petition her for aid in constructing coastal defences, for what is the ocean but another bastion?
With Celestial fire coursing through their veins, quaffed without hesitation from a jade goblet, the Dragon Emperor's honour guard shall never again know fatigue.
Retired Gate Masters – with the Dragon Emperor's tacit approval – often train underworld denizens in the ways of the Jade Warriors. In this way, even criminals are taught balance.
Some say meditation is relaxation. This is a grave misconception, for Yang meditation amplifies the will and dampens all need. Its most capable practitioners can go days without rest or fodder.
The House of Secrets skirts the edges of morality and legality, but a carefully-worded edict would further legitimise its renegade wizards. In turn, it would share its best and brightest with us.
It is on the backs of the hard-working commonfolk that every noble of Cathay stands, and it is past time they were shown gratitude. Send forth for the finest dishes in all the Celestial Empire!
Every child of Cathay is taught to fear the Great Enemy, but as adulthood descends, so too does temptation grow. Mandatory re-education and thrice-daily prayer to the Dragon Emperor is thus required.
A single brass lever activates thousands of pulleys, arranged in a dense lattice even the most brilliant of minds could not untangle, and quickly drags the Compass into shuddering arrangement.
Once freed from doubt, fear and distrust, their minds governed only by their absolute devotion to the Dragon Emperor, the Celestial legion shall move like the Eight Winds themselves.
By harnessing the magic of Azyr, Xen Yang may divine what is to come, and thus He shall know the hour of our need. When He tells His faithful that hour has not yet come, they shall believe Him.
By augmenting each missile's tip with shards of the Celestial Dragon's most favoured stone, they shall become able to pierce even the strongest steel.
The Terracotta Sentinels are ancient indeed, but the Celestial Court believes it can recreate the invocations Xen Yang used to infuse their stone forms with a semblance of life so long ago.

The Moon Empress weeps for every fallen child of Cathay. For this reason, she has been known to walk amongst those who follow her creed, disguised as a peasant healer, tending to the wounded and dying.
Some mistake darkness for wickedness. Those who worship Quai Yin know that, in truth, darkness is purity, and to give themselves to the peace of night will answer their every need.
Great feats of archery, great deeds of subterfuge, great acts of charity: this is how the Moon Dragon's blessed favour is won.
When its powder is laced with deadly Warpstone, courtesy of the House of Secrets' e'er-scheming Alchemists, each fresh Fire Rain rocket can be produced for a fraction of its former cost.
Come the next rainstorm, a system of canals and reservoirs can capture and share the Dragon River's over-spilling, mystic waters far and wide. And thus, the Yin shall flow.
Vermillion Warbird hatchlings, before they reach full and fiery maturity, may be used as spotters, scattering harmless dancing flames in the vicinity of Crane Gunners' distant targets.

When not dousing the Dragon Emperor's foes in purifying flame, the Dragon Fire Throwers mounted upon a Sky-Junk's perimeter can belch their emissions towards the craft's rear, further increasing thrust.

Harmony brings unity, and unity brings efficiency. The warriors of wind and field must be taught to trust one another implicitly, for each is an extension of the Dragon Emperor's will, fighting as one.
More space on the Ivory Road means more capacity for the Caravans leaving Shang-Yang.
Cathay's provincial troops are loyal and numberless, but they are crude and unrefined soldiers. There is such great potential in them, waiting only to be unlocked.
A system of bellows and fine brass funnels ensures that escaped heat is recaptured and reused rather than wasted, thus granting greater lift and range for our Sky Lanterns.
As more and more accursed books are sealed, bigger and bigger temples are built, and Sigmar’s blessings smile upon us.
“The damned will fear us as we push forwards with unbridled wrath – AND THEY WILL BE DESTROYED!”
Hearts pound like war drums, veins burn with primal fire, sinews tighten into iron, and the rage, oh the rage, is transcendent in its intensity. Such endless, glorious slaughter there shall be!
Though carnage is its own reward, if offered sufficient tribute the Skull Throne may on occasion grant unto us great tools of destruction. Our fury shall be augmented by legendary steel.
An ocean of hatred! A flood of fury! A spreading sea of purest rage and unbound wrath! All must hear the call to slaughter!
Destruction alone will not suffice. We are not animals! We are crusaders, driven by fury and fervour in equal measure, and we will exact the tribute that great Kharneth is due.

Some believe we simply rejoice in destruction, and do not understand that it is undiluted hatred that drives us on. As we sup upon their lifeblood by the gallon, howling to the skies, all will know the truth.
Hate is our armour. Fury is our shield. Rage is our bulwark. Magic? Pah! It is worthless trickery that shall never, ever dim our Daemons' limitless and eternal wrath.

Those who give themselves, body and soul, to the fury within shall never again require sustenance or reward. Hunger, thirst, desire, avarice – they will be liberated from such petty concerns. Only hatred shall remain.

As the Blood God's brass throne room fills to the ceiling with freshly-harvested skulls, we will unleash rage to shake this world to its very core! As awe-struck as they are terrified, all will quail before our everlasting fury!
None may refuse the call of slaughter, for it is the call of glory, honour, destiny and destruction.
Let the bone bounty pour forth, for every harvested skull is a paean to the glory of war, and to the immortal might of the Murder God.
If we are to triumph upon every battlefield, if we are to bathe in the blood of our every enemy, we must lure legendary warriors beyond compare to our murderous cause. Put out the call!
We will dig trophies from the ashes, seize wealth from the ruins, tear trinkets from the corpses, and then we will know the Skull Throne's approval for these blood-soaked tributes.

Only once this world is scrubbed clean of the decadent Slaaneshi can it know honour. It is our great privilege to slaughter the Perfect Prince's venal fools, and a responsibility we shall never shirk.
Do not lose heart, for failure is a but an opportunity to grow stronger, and thus another stepping stone to glory. There will, after all, always be more blood to spill.
Even the mindless cannot resist the drums of war. And even the most wretched and broken of beings can call upon the might of Kharneth, if it serves slaughter's cause.
Our beasts of battle shall fear no foe, no matter how great or how unnatural. A kill is a kill, and flesh is flesh. The more of it there is, the more there is to rip and tear.
The intoxicating thrill of savage victory shall become headier than ever, and our thirst for the kill will know no bounds. Praise the Skull Throne!
As we gaze upon lands riven by bloodshed and hatred, our hearts swell with pride, knowing that we have served the Hunter of Souls well.
Steadfast belief in our skills and our tools of war guarantees greater tribute. The more we value our own prowess in battle, the more fresh skulls there shall be.
Our great deeds attract the attention of a great warrior – a scar-cloaked and blood-soaked champion of Kharneth. With this legend of warfare at our side, unprecedented new heights of glory await us.
The slaughter has been glorious, our skill has been unmatched, and the pride we take in each fresh kill has never been greater. We are deserving of tribute.

Slice the throats of the runts, and let their superior brethren feast upon their corpses. Only the largest, strongest and most quick-tempered of breeding stock may be permitted to join Khorne's blood legion.
It is our unshakeable self-belief, not mere flesh, which sustains the hordes of Kharneth. Shrug off all wounds! Do not flinch at lost limbs or gored organs!

Believe in victory, and victory shall come to pass. Believe that we will be showered in the skulls of the fallen, and we will be showered in the skulls of the fallen. Believe in Lord Khorne, for He believes in us.
As magic, the tool of weaklings and deceivers, is anathema to the will of Khorne, so too do our war-beasts despise all sorcery. As the accursed Winds blow, their ferocity shall only grow.
No matter how many foes' bones we blunt our blades upon, there can be no complacency, no final moment of triumph. We must forever prove that our skill, and our fury, is unmatched.
Let the bodies pile up, let the land run red with blood, let the scars accumulate upon our hides, and then, only then, will the Lord of Murder show His approval.
Should one of our bloodthirsty kin fall in battle, simply step across their corpse and slay their killer, knowing that ever more of Khorne's Daemons stand behind us. The Blood Lord provides, always!
The Feet of Khorne will not succumb to the agony of fire. They will thrive upon it! Our Soulcrushers will be forged anew in the scorching flames, battle-frenzied and unstoppable!
The merest scent of carnage shall rouse our Doombulls into a frenzied rage – perfect killing machines without mercy or restraint, a sight to awe even the most battle-weary of Daemons.

It is spirit and skill, not the physical limitations of brass and bone, that govern the murderous wrath of our Hellforged Bellowers. Let them be fused with our Bloodletters' unholy purpose, and they will maim and slay like never before.
Raw hunks of gore bring the Skull Throne only meagre satisfaction. Our Daemons must become artisans of butchery, harvesting pristine and undamaged skulls from their foes' mutilated' corpses.
Let our murderous legion reach a rapturous crescendo of slaughter – an unprecedented symphony of destruction, a brand new zenith of murderous fury.
So many bodies rended. So many skulls harvested. Our furious deeds shall birth a great storm of wrath, to rain down upon every soul in every land. All shall heed the Blood God's call!
The Skull Throne's Greater Daemons are wrath incarnate, pure fury made corporeal. As our blood legion's lethal rage swells and swells, ever more Deathbringers shall join their axes to ours.
Death is no obstacle to bloodlust, for Khornate fury is immortal. Those Daemons slain in glorious battle shall swiftly be reborn, hungry for savage vengeance.
So consumed by ferocity shall our horde be that all rest will forever be denied to them. For every moment of their furious existence, they will think only of the next kill.
As their blood boils with eternal murder-lust, our Juggers will become living engines of destruction, their incandescent rage rendering them immune to fear or exhaustion.

The slain Daemon imprisoned within every Soul Grinder rages to return to their physical form, but only though copious slaughter can this come to pass. Let us aid our Clinkerspawns' cause by granting them furious new might.
Wrath brings war. War brings death. Death brings skulls. Skulls bring glory. Thus: skulls for the Skull Throne! Skulls for the Skull Throne! Skulls for the Skull Throne!
No gods! No kings! Only Khorne! It is in His name that we wage our eternal war upon order, and it is by His grace that we shall be granted the tools of triumph.
Life, in all its meekness and indulgence, is an affront to the God of Murder! Life must be refused! Life must be destroyed!
Wherever there is hatred, wherever there is fury, a red door is opened. Through it strides Kharneth's baying legion of butchers, summoned into being by unchecked resentment, conflict and disorder.
No weapon nor any spell of destruction can slow the Blood God's greatest warriors, for they simply refuse pain. Wounds are for the weak! The strong fight on, always.
Defeat is impossible! Victory is inevitable! The Skull Throne expects, and we shall not disappoint! When the killing is done, we shall bathe in glory. But, of course, the killing is never done…
Peace is the greatest of insults to the servants of blood. Indeed, a true champion of Khorne can refuse no battle, and will willingly move mountains to join the gore-soaked fray.
Refuse all need! Refuse all want! These are the worthless concerns of mortals. The honour of proving ourselves before Khorne is the only sustenance we require.
When our foes strike like cowards from afar, the Hunter of Souls expects that we simply rebuff their craven fusillades. Then, our wrath undimmed, we close for the kill.
When brothers in blood go to war against one another, it will be a fight like no other. There is no foe more pitiless, no foe more brutal, than our own kin.
The mortal brutes are powerful indeed, with might to rival our own, but in knowing they face this deadliest of challenges, the blood legion will excel.
Cowards that they are, the meddling Raven's mutants will deploy sorcery and trickery against us. Fortunately, there is no magic that can drive the scent of blood from our nostrils.
Those mortals who have sold their souls to Ruin believe themselves to be the equal of Daemons. When they lie writhing on the battlefield, blood pouring from their wounds, they will know the truth.
No disease, no matter how foul, can survive the scorching flames of Kharneth's rage. As we rend these festering wretches limb from limb, we shall burn all taint from them.
The stone-faced mortals of Kislev possess uncommon endurance, but even their steel will shatter beneath our pounding hooves and lacerating blades.
No longer will the hated Dragon Emperor impede Kharneth's bloody crusade! We will march through his volleys and fusillades as if they were nothing!
It matters not what undeserved gifts this fallen mortal has stolen from the Gods. We will simply carve a path through whatever horrors he dares arrays against us.
Fight with courage, slay only worthy foes, and the Lord of Murder shall be your shield in the glorious battles to come.
Let them come. Let them try. We will not be bowed! We will not be broken! We will remain steadfast, always!
Not one inch of Kharneth's ground can be lost. The harder our foe strikes against us, the more unwavering our courage shall be.
Courage, honour and unchecked ferocity: these are the virtues to which we all must aspire. Let us summon forth great champions of carnage to show our lesser forces the way.
Wherever there is fear, there can be no honour. The solution is simple: remove all fear, and only courage shall remain.
Fear not the subterfuge of cowards. Their shameful blades shall break against our hides, for our righteous rage is all the armour we require.
The Blood God approves of the great and glorious battles we fight in His name. He shall grant unto us His mightiest warriors, borne atop His most fearsome beasts.
Every wound a triumph! Every scar a trophy! Every fresh gouge a mark of honour! Shrug off the blade's bite, and know the heat of battle once more!
In the Endless Steppes, nothing will grow in the grip of winter, so preserving food for the long haul is not just practical, but essential.
This ingenious design not only enables efficient deflection of blows, but can also be hooked around an opponent's shield or haul a rider from their mount.
Hides and skins are tanned to protect and make them more durable in the harsh, northern conditions.
The ancient ways of the Old Religion are embedded and enmeshed within the lives of the ordinary Kislevites who toil the land.
The ancient ways of the Old Religion are enmeshed within the lives of the ordinary Kislevites who toil the land.
It is thought the natural state of affairs that the more civilised southern tribe should rule over the simple peoples of the north.
An important skill for acolytes of the Ice Court is learning to carve and shape its abundance through manipulation of the highly-volatile Ice Magic.
The added downforce provided by these upright wooden bracings makes for much sturdier sleds which are far less likely to overturn during swift manoeuvres on the ice.

Gaze now in despair at the coils of the column that rises from the red-hot sand. Crowned by baleful orbs, they gleam with the eddying hues of sombre iris.
Imbued with the undying will of Nehekhara's kings, the sacred war-statuary grant a measure of their stone-like resilience and ceaseless vigilance to the legions.
The invention – and macabre opulence – of Nehekharan war chariots swelled their hosts, for it was deemed indecorous for highborn blood to touch the brutish draught beasts.
Even in Undeath, the nomads of the arid wastes enjoy the freedom conferred by the tyrants of old, in return for answering the dynasty's summons.
Through a gruelling redoubling of effort, incantations that rekindle the inanimate shell can tip a soul from the very scales of the God of the Underworld.
Clad in morbid regalia and with ceremonial arms at the ready, the king's elite emerge from their upright sarcophagi to serve their rancorous sovereign.
The grim custodians of these bone-woven catapults are not perturbed by gurgling pleas seeping from the cadavers nailed to their masts – quite the opposite, in fact!
Be they sentries of the inner sanctums enshrined in vast lycea or superstitiously-interred in the deepest desert chasms, these mythical colossi are difficult to disentomb.
The Winds of Magic shift through a fountain of indescribable colours as, somewhere far beyond, the Raven laughs.
To remain in stasis is a fate worse than even the cruellest death. Praise the Architect of Fate, for He brings blessed change – and not a moment too soon.
The mind is the one true battlefield. Only by luring more mortals to His ineffable cause can Lord Tzeentch prevail in the Great Game.
To look upon the standard of Tzeentch, crawling with eldritch, multi-hued symbols and tempestuous energies, is to look upon madness writ in living cloth.
The puppeteering of space and time is accompanied by the acrid-sweet smell of burning reality, and the sense of something serpentine tunnelling through one's mind.
Once sufficient raw material is seized in the name of the Great Sorcerer, it is but child's play to transmute its essence into materials of great value.
Most believe that mutation is random, but the faithful know that Tzeentch's instructions for how the flesh will one day warp are inscribed upon the very fibres of one's being.
Vision is illusion. In this, we are all of us but the puppets of Tzeeneth, and he severs and re-ties our strings at will.
The flesh writhes and warps, taking on ever-changing, disorientating new forms most minds cannot focus on, seeming even to spasm in and out of existence.
Tzeentch listens. Tzeentch sees. Tzeentch knows.
Hail the writhing fire of change! All glory to the true nature of Chaos!
Magic is matter, and matter is magic. Both, behind the vaunted but illusory rules of reality, are in a constant state of glorious flux.
The Raven's light dances across flesh – and then through it, illuminating it with cascades of indescribable colour from within. In this way, existence is revealed as illusion.
None can resist the portal's whispered call – but all consumed by it will proceed on their way to oblivion.
Knowledge is both source and fuel for the Raven God's timeless, limitless power. Thus, there must always be more knowledge.
Should one refuse to open their eyes to truth, it is only right that they should be parted from them.
The sound is a chilling howl from the void, a siren song of madness that strips reason from even the strongest mind.
The iridescent waters of the Well of Eternity reveal all to Tzeentch's patient gaze.
The unseen Mark of Tzeentch is inscribed upon every stone in every land, for this is His design. To those granted the Raven's sight, the bounties are great indeed.
All knowledge belongs to the Bringer of Change, and he will reclaim it at will.
Bony knuckles inside the brain, kneading, coaxing, enraging – stoking eternal hatred.
Such power there is in words. Power that belongs only to the Raven God.
Searing scarlet, blinding blue, glorious gold: these are the writhing colours of Tzeentch's uncanny balefire.
The squealing giggle of a single Horror can shred mortal minds to ribbons. This is why great Tzeentch provides an ever-swelling legion of these Whirling Destroyers.
Ask miracles of the Impossible Fortress and ye shall receive. For what is wealth to Tzeentch but a whisper upon the breeze?
The witless mortals call it 'magic'. Here is the truth of the matter: this great energy is Change itself given eldritch form, and Tzeentch decrees to whom it is allocated.
The Changer of Ways sees the secret hatred within, the simmering greed behind the mask of friendship. That is how He makes puppets of us all.
The Fool God Nurgle, and his flat circles of unchanging time. Let there be disruption! Let there be Change!
Blue and gold are His colours. Nine is His number. The Raven is His totem. Infinite is His knowledge.
Whispering doubt. Hissing mistrust. Murmured envy. The Great Conspirator's dark will makes a mockery of allegiance, courage and friendship alike.
Which caused which – the writhing, sanity-stripping runes or the unnaturally shifting steel that bears them? Only Tzeentch knows.
Time is but a mirage, a self-deception employed by mortals to impose order upon madness. Should the Changer will it this futile illusion may be dispelled.
Only by Tzeentch's will do any of us draw breath. Due gratitude must be shown.
From the shadows, He watches. He sees the darkness behind the lies. He pulls at unseen strings, and summons forth tumult and turmoil.
Let dull metal become lustrous gold. For the Changer of Ways, this requires only a thought.
From the forbidden tomes of Tzeentch, a fresh incantation to pluck a Shrieking Skyray from the heavens and bind it to His servitor's will.
All of this has happened before, and all of this shall happen again and again. Only Tzeentch decides the when.
Howling mania. Writhing tendrils. An abundance of warped limbs. Gift upon gift upon unbearable gift, by the grace of the Changer.
The honour of serving The Great Schemer's eternal, ineffable will is both wage and fuel for His shrieking legion of change.
A kaleidoscope of blazing colour, hypnotic in its majesty. Before those engulfed by it are reduced to ashes, they will witness the truth.
Deep within the Crystal Labyrinth, the Weaver of Fates pulls at the strings of time. Thus do his myriad servants grow in strength and wisdom at unnatural pace.
Ancient knowledge, arcane deceptions and the exquisite gift of insanity: to His most faithful, Tzeentch bestows Ruinous blessings.
Horrors are wildly unstable by nature, caught only in a brief dalliance with existence, but the correct incantations may bind them to greater corporeality.
Deception is its own reward. Come what may, the Weaver of Fates rejoices when a long-planned scheme is at last revealed.
Only a fool believes they make their own choices. The Great Conspirator has known their mind since the moment of their creation.
Lost ruts - long-forgotten ways once trod by hoof - have been revealed; the Bray-Shamans urge their use.
Such wondrous blessings from our glorious masters.
Blood-grounds are where the Beastmen range, hunting and slaughtering. New grounds mean fresh prey to sate their hunger.
Most bountiful is the herdstone inscribed with the most fell of runes and doused in hated enemy blood.
Who cares for man-filth honour? Slaying and blood is all the Gods want, even if that is achieved from afar!
Beastmen are not ‘quiet’ revellers; it doesn’t take much to amplify their natural aggression and rage.
We are Children of Chaos; we embrace our pedigree!
Beastmen excel at ambushing - wiser Gors know all the beast-paths and so can surround their prey more quickly.
The most forbidden rituals are enacted by a willing Bray-Shaman, whose soul is forfeit should the fickle Gods decree it.
All servants of the Ruinous Powers – horned or no – crave the gaze of the Dark Gods.
The knowledge that Gors and Minotaurs may wallow in filth and enemy blood will draw many more from afar.
Beastmen have a penchant for grim fetishes, especially those gathered from mannish foes.
The hearts of Beastmen are blackened with evil, but only those with the darkest of souls rise to prominence.
The Gors gather hives of pestilent corruption, fostered by the Beastlords as recruiting grounds for their herds.
Larger blades require stronger arms, for those wielding such massive weapons can literally cleave man-filth in twain.
An agent of the Chaos Gods, acting in their stead, will be granted favour… until they fail.
Slay the unwilling during blackest night in view of the Dark Moon.
On such dire days - on the eve of the End Times - all the Cloven Ones are empowered.
The hunt is eternal; it never began, it shall never end. It always was.
Pity the poor defenders of Kalkengard, hung from its trees and ruined, rocky spires as meat for hungry Minotaurs.
On war's path tread the slaves to darkness; the lost, the damned, and the behorned.
Should the warherds please their Dark Masters they are blessed with a dark fortitude.
Plant the seed and watch corruption blossom.
Gors of purest, spiteful intent. It is no wonder they share a bond with the lesser beasts.
When a Beastman is visited by twisted visions, it knows its Ruinous Masters have delivered a message, a clue, or a boon…
Quick to temper and impossible to tame, such fierceness should be fostered if it cannot be controlled.
Praise the power of Chaos, and revel in its bounties.
The aloof creator of the Elves keeps his thoughts and plans well hidden from mortal eyes.
As the rulers of the heavens, the Cadai watch over the Asrai.
Only a fool claims to have nothing to learn, the wise seek the guidance of Hoeth, Lord of Wisdom.
Goddess of the Harvest and Bountiful Land, Isha is beloved by all the Elves of Athel Loren.
Goddess of the Harvest and Bountiful Land, Isha is beloved by all the Elves of Athel Loren.
This powerful God of the Hunt sits side by side with his immortal love, Isha, at the heart of the Elven pantheon.
Protector of all that is hidden and lost, Ladrielle comes to the aid of those who wander the dark places of the world.
When Elves dream of a great undertaking, it is Lileath whispering to them as they sleep.
Loec the Trickster protects the souls of Wood Elves from Slaanesh's perverse, Ruinous reach.
Wisest of all who dwell in the forest of Athel Loren, the Ancients have forgotten more than most Elves learn in a lifetime.
Vaul the Maker works tirelessly to craft weapons to aid the Elves in the battles to come.
Wrath and fire - the gifts that Addaioth offers those who worship him.
Goddess of the Savage Hunt and woman spurned, Anath Raema's heart rots with vengeance.
They who give themselves over to the pursuit of pleasure would do well to court the favour of Atharti.
The Gods of the Underworld are treacherous, but their power is undeniable.
Those who seek a quiet life, away from society, honour Drakira.
Those who yearn to fight in the name of honour must seek out Eldrazor.
For those that crave the destruction of their enemies, Ellinill is always happy to help.
In her dark and gloomy kingdom, Ereth Khial plots new ways to reclaim the souls of the dead from Slaanesh.
The Elves of Athel Loren know that each deity has a time and place.
The Dark Mistress of Magic, Hekarti, draws those who worship her to the darker side of magic.
Hukon is the Elven God of Earthquakes and one of the few surviving members of the Ellinilli.
The Asrai worship where they will, choosing to honour the gods that best fit their personalities.
The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.
The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.
Also known as the Crone, Morai Heg is the only god in the Elven pantheon who is neither Cadai or Cytharai.
The secrets of the Underworld are forbidden to those of the mortal realm. Nethu guards the pathways between them.
Dark spirits of the Deepwood, they take the Tree Kin's very souls.
“The King decrees that from this day forth, the forests of Bretonnia be made safe from the Beastmen’s Ruinous bane.”
The King decrees that the scourge of Chaos be stopped at all costs and the land delivered to safety.
The King decrees that the shores be secured against the vile raiders from Naggarond.
“The King decrees that the Greenskin blight be utterly annihilated wherever, whenever, and however possible!"
Too long have the Greenskins pillaged Bretonnian lands.
“The King decrees that Bretonnians must double their efforts to defend the Kingdom against the barbaric forces of the North.”
Across the Sea of Claws lies an ancient threat; pay it the utmost attention, lest it grows too near.
The King decrees that the sewers should not provide refuge to abominations.
The King decrees that the trade routes will suffer no more harassment from desert bone-crawlers.
The King decrees that the threat of Unliving incursions be foremost in the collective mind of the kingdom.
The King decrees that the malevolent forces of Athel Loren must be kept at bay.
No longer can a bad workman blame his tools…
The wider the plough, the higher the yield, in less time.
Irrigation ensures that the fields are watered and the people fed, no matter the season.
The less we depend on the elements, the greater our control over our food supplies.
Steeds shod by a trained farrier have better purchase upon the roads and blessed ground of fair Bretonnia.
The horses of Bretonnia are treated better than the smallfolk. Hay stores, for example, allow horses to feed all year round.
Blinker hoods restrict the eyesight of horses, making the beasts easier to control.
Bigger bobbins are better bobbins. It is known.
The fruit of such a loom is industry in abundance.
Time spent schooling the workers pays dividends later.
For some, appearances are everything - regardless of the truth of the matter.
Stealing or copying techniques and forge designs from their Empire neighbours improves Bretonnian metalworking.
Building on breakthroughs in forge-design, kilns that can reach higher temperatures produce better earthenware.
Improve the process and the results look after themselves.
The designs of these mighty furnaces have been taken from Nuln, and are used to create hardened plate.
Folding steel takes great skill; the more folds, the stronger and sharper the blade.
Tournaments are a way for noble knights to gain honour and maintain martial skills during rare glimpses of peacetime.
The poor must be cared for, just enough to ensure productivity.
Know your population, know the size of your army.
For what is a peasant without his pitchfork?
“Rejoice, peasants! For a generous Knight of Bretonnia provides for you!”
While wood is plentiful, carpentry skills remain relatively rare and so are prized in Bretonnia.
Once the town census has been undertaken, its easy to round the peons up for military service.
For those not born into nobility, there are few ways to gain the Lady's favour.
Those peasants skilled at bow-making are ordered to do it year round, instead of supplying a village's quota.
This requires educated men, often those who have studied abroad in the universities of Estalia or the Empire.
Better woodworking techniques allow for longer, more sturdy spears and polearms.
Paladins are expected to donate large sums of their inheritance to the cult of the Lady.
Banish uncertainty: invest in the kingdom's future.
A seaworthy fleet keeps the economy afloat.
Bribing the harbourmaster pays dividends on import duties.
Artois, where the unified dukedoms swore fealty to the Uniter.
Bastonne, birthplace of the Uniter and the source of his bloodline.
Manann is more than a mere deity; he is a source of livelihood for many Bordelen citizens.
King Leoncoeur leads Bretonnia; his symbol, the Shield of Couronne.
The sons of Carcassonne bear the symbol of the sword, the insignia of their warrior-culture.
The ongoing Errantry Wars across the sea need constant political and financial support.
Lyonesse, the homeland of the most devoted of all the Grail Companions.
The King knows that it cannot be Bretonnia alone which stems the tide of filth - diplomats and envoys are required to broker alliances.
Among the cliffs, peaks, and mountain ranges, the pegasi soar.
Every Bretonnian Lord knows that honour and chivalry come before everything.
One people, one land – all shall know its glory and grandeur.
For those who dwell in the shadow of Chaos, monster hunting is a most savage pleasure.
Nowhere else but under the shadow of Chaos are such brutish and degenerate killers nurtured and bred.
Prolonged exposure to the dark energies of the bitter, frozen north creates the toughest and most monstrous freaks.
For some abominations of the north, a mere whiff of blood is enough to lose all restraint.
The eerie green glow of the Dark Moon calls out all manner of feral monstrosities from the Norscan wilderness.
A hunter without knowledge of his quarry is like a warrior without knowledge of his enemy.
“To kill the beast, you must think like the beast."
Weapons and armour are not the only apparatus of war – so too are the tools used to forge them.
A piece of armour is no harder than the anvil upon which it is fashioned.
Without their aptly-formed instruments of death, the Northmen would be much less effective killers.
Sharper throwing-axes forged in larger numbers mean more dismemberment and decapitation on the battlefield.
With the right armour, a Marauder’s mare can trample several enemy lines before taking significant damage.
The correct expertise and equipment enables the Marauders' swift, blood-fed steeds to be ridden at their greatest speeds.
Give a captive a sword and he becomes an expendable sparring partner.
Like an unspoilt bauble waiting to be ravaged and plundered, the New World beckons.
The arrogance of these Elves, they think they know how to deal pain? We shall show them true pain!
With sorcerous secrets revealed, the Balefiends will be drawn - like moths to a flame.
The only fit fate for these preening, foppish beanpoles is to be cut, cleaved and butchered.
Steal from the Elves the things that which makes them ‘worthy’; their methods of subterfuge, their machinations of intrigue.
Hunt the cold-bloods, defile their sacred spaces, pillage and take all we can!
Take from the reptiles all they hold dear - their precious secrets.
Slaughter the ratmen - the step-children of our Dark Lords. We are the true inheritors!
The vile secrets of the Skaven - their devious designs - are ripe for plunder.
Deserts are for the dead, but the tomb-lurkers insist they live. Show them the truth.
Within their tombs is knowledge as ancient as the Dark Masters, take it.
The war never ends because combatants slain are rarely dead for long...
The Vampire Coast's vast hoards of stolen treasure shall be yours. The gold, maps and logs within will bring you advantage.
Whether fighting at sea or on land, the longship Marauders are the most seasoned veterans of the Norscan tribes.
Sailing into the unknown is always easier with more space for supplies.
When the Marauders’ eagerness for despoilment is nurtured, vast distances can be covered between raids.
“Once you’ve rowed the breadth of the Middle Sea a few times, relentless slaughter does little to tire you…”
Every new war brings the Marauders bloody, gore-drenched glory in battle, whether in victory or in death.
The opulent, pompous kingdoms of men and Dwarfs sit on a vast wealth that waits to be taken.
Svengar’s defeat at L’Anguille was an age ago - the Bretonnian Dukes shall soon fall!
The lavish lands of Bretonnia’s capital provide powerful steeds, fertile lands, and tradable resources in abundance.
The peaceful principalities of the southernmost men need to be shown the true savagery of the north!
Whether it is material wealth, or just good ideas, all manner of assets can be stolen from organised men.
Entrenched in their Holds, the stunties fiercely protect their lucrative mines, offering both a good fight and valuable plunder.
The closely-guarded knowledge of Dwarf construction and resource excavation techniques will be mysterious no longer!
To the east lie lands ripe for plundering – the treasuries and loot piles of Empire-men, Vampires, and Greenskins.
The soft men of the Empire think themselves the pinnacle of civilisation – time to bring them down a notch!
Despoil the Empire’s heartland, rip the Colleges of Magic from their foundations – only then will their secrets be revealed.
Clogging up the land with soulless vessels, the Vampires and their Necromantic allies are a scourge to be eradicated.
The Vampires and Undead, while despicable, are masters of subterfuge and know the secrets of mortal convalescence.
The Greenskins’ love for war almost matches that of the Norscan tribes – let savagery be met with savagery!
The primitive Greenskin gods are hard to make sense of, but their mystical secrets are valuable to any warmonger.
From afar, let us watch the sweet flame engulf their precious tree-kin!
Betwixt pine and bark but ash now lay knowledge innate to the Wood Elves – ours for the taking.
Let the Marauders gather under their Ruinous masters' eternal gaze.
Khorne desires skulls, so gifts his followers with the initiative to find them. Every. Single. One.
Rituals performed to please the Gods may see an increase in favour.
Fell runes that burn the eyes when looked upon adorn Marauder banners, showing a tribe's true devotion.
The names of the worthy, decided by violent duel.
Stragglers will not be entertained. If you can't keep the pace, you are food for the Warhounds.
Tributes and monuments to the Dark Powers ensure the Chaos Gods' favour.
The Warriors of Chaos carry dark banners, bearing sigils and runes that writhe as if alive.
All Chaos Warriors aspire to great deeds in the Chaos Gods' name, for Daemonhood awaits the greatest of their number.
Such a generous gift is the thousand twisted blessings, think of all the needle teeth and tentacles it bestows.
Chaos Warriors have been touched by Chaos, gaining fighting abilities far beyond those of normal men.
The Blood God never tires of hearing the war cry screamed in his name.
Like the banners held by infantry, the Knights of Chaos ride to war with blasphemous pennants.
All hope to catch the attention of the Gods, gathering where they think the Chaos Gods will be looking.
The elite of the Chaos Warriors are the Chosen and the Chaos Knights. They are the Dark Gods' willing slaves.
Chaos Armour, inscribed with powerful litanies of hate, will glow hot and vengeful when struck.
The Chaos Gods grow impatient. Lending a sliver of majesty, they enable their followers to march faster.
Powerful beasts and engines are enhanced if under the command of the Dark Gods.
Even more precious than Chaos Armour, this heavy plate is imbued with Daemonic essence.
To be granted such favour is to be given untold power and a chance to rise above the ranks.
The arms of a Chaos Knight are imbued with a small but not inconsequential amount of Unholy power.
Behold the Herald of Doom, a familiar eager to spread discord and panic with news that the Giants come.
When ultimate power is the prize, expect a perilous journey indeed…
Chaos is a seductive force.
Once promises have been made, the champion is far along the road to damnation.
Final pledges are made by aspirants who have long since bargained away their souls for ultimate power.
A pact with the Dark Gods should not be taken lightly.
A powerful, authoritative voice in any Hold, the Guilds dominate Dwarfen civil life, controlling trade, finances and labour.
Dwarf treasuries are often as deep as their vaults… which can be very deep!
To grow the Everlasting Realm, the Guilds send subsidies to make settlements old and new sustainable.
Nepotism is not a dirty word in Dwarf society. The Guilds encourage it, for family honour is prized.
Grumpy, straight-talking Dwarfs do not make the best diplomats, yet some are better at it than others!
The august Toolmakers are a young but powerful Guild, as all Dawi that practise a craft need tools.
When a Dawi is in need of decent hammer or axe, the tool market is the place to find it.
Thanes speak with the word of their King, and so the Guilds' rarely question such direct commands.
As Dwarf Guilds wield such power, it makes sense that the Clans keep an eye on them, ensuring competence and honesty.
Dwarfen Emissaries use their forbearance of other races to play the game of diplomacy as well as any Elf, lacing palms with oathgold as needed.
In the lower deeps of any Hold are the sealed vaults. They are cool and dark, perfect for storing foodstuffs and other vital supplies.
Dwarf grinding stones are always perfectly round and decorated with geometric scrawls and runes, usually of Valaya's making.
Dwarfholds tend to trade with each other via the Underway, which keeps prying eyes out of Dawi business.
Karaz Ankor states that, while all Dwarfholds swear fealty to the High King, they are ruled independently.
Every Dwarf must make unbreakable oaths to his King. Only the most scraggiest of beard-wearers would think to break them.
Dwarfs are not ones for innovation, but refining a process to perfection is a totally different matter!
Dwarfen picks of Gromril are rare, but only needed when mining for star-iron ore, as like finds like.
The Royal Clan is entitled to its tithe. The Reckoners guarantee that the Guilds pay up.
Thorgrim brooks no fools, Dawi or otherwise. He is stern - even for a High King - and his authority is absolute.
Steam-powered automated drills are a recent, if noisy, invention by the Engineers' Guild.
Dwarf prospectors are experienced miners. It is said they can even uncover new seams by smell rather than sight.
Dwarfs are industrious. When the Guilds call for construction, their members gather and work their beards off!
The tombs of the Ancestors are shrines, for Dwarfs revere age, experience and unbroken blood lines.
Some tombs lay closed, forever sealed with stones covered in ancient runes that glow when evil lurks nearby.
The 'Grims' - small Dwarf tokens attached to their products - are a sign of quality even the manlings understand.
Using tar and hide, the Dwarfs can effectively waterproof certain supplies that are otherwise prone to spoilage.
Along with the Engineers, the Construction Guilds are some of the most powerful, for every Dwarf needs a home.
The grander the Throne Chamber, the more envious and intimidated the King's audience or 'guests' will be.
Dwarf Runepriests are rare, but when they visit the Holds they inscribe the Protection of Valaya upon home and hearth.
It is in the Guild halls where the ruling councils meet to discuss policy, tariffs, and to further their goals.
Thanks to the Guilds, Dwarfs excel at getting resources out of the ground - no matter how deep!
The Runepriests bestow Grungni's Blessing on Guild works, ensuring profitable ventures for all.
The putting together of great Dwarfen heads always results in the optimal solution, even when facing the foulest, most abominable problem.
When the Thanes call to gather the throngs, it is the Clans that answer, for they have bonds stronger than Gromril.
Every Dwarf practices a trade, but as war is common each Clan readily forms into one or more regiments.
Once word is given that it's war, the message quickly passes down the ranks from Kings to Lords to Thanes.
As with all Dawi Guilds, the Dwarf warrior tradition also follows the path of apprentice, journeyman and master.
Puresteel crossbows are precision-crafted instruments, able to accurately deliver death from afar.
All members of the Clan will answer its call, swearing oaths against those who have wronged them.
The resolve of the Dwarfs is legendary. Once they are set upon a task, nothing can stop them.
By standing atop an Oath Stone, followers' resolve is increased, ensuring a champion's foes can find him in the scrum.
Dwarfen wagon trains transport case loads of shot, buckets of crossbow bolts, and casks of black powder to the coming fight.
Deadeyes can pick off a grobi's nose at a hundred paces. For really good ones, it's twice that range.
Dwarfs excel at shieldwalls. Over the years, the Guilds, at the Clans' request, have experimented with interlocking shield designs.
A Dawi Lord's retainers are his loyal servants and bodyguards, be they shield or throne bearers.
Dwarfs prefer accuracy to firing rates, as they realise that increased firepower does not necessarily cause higher casualties.
The Clans constantly order in black powder and make demands for better quality, deadlier batches as well.
If you want a job doing properly, albeit with some moaning, then get a Longbeard.
No Longbeard would ever consider breaking an oath. If he promised to come, there he will be.
Dwarfen weaponsmithing is the finest in the world - a gift from the Guilds to their fellow Clans-kin.
The alchemical brew used to fuel the flaming drakeguns can be made more potent, if a tad more unstable…
Skilled in fighting at the vanguard of the Dwarfs’ main force, Rangers fulfil a dangerous role fraught with risk and unimaginable peril.
Dwarfs like to drink, sing and tell tall-tales. However, some stories concerning veterans may actually be true.
A rolling Dwarfen song contains many verses and a constant rhythm, used to keep in step and up to pace.
Dwarfen runes empower weapons already forged by the finest smiths, making a potent axe a truly deadly item.
Artillery Engineers soon found that the benefit of keeping certain parts modular allowed for improvements in the manufacturing process.
Again the Dwarfen forges speak, casting a new type of ammunition - large shells filled with cinderblast.
In the deeps, the Ironbreakers are always on call, ready to defend the Hold from threats below.
The so-called "Iron Price" is not the wage, but the cost of having troops away from normal duty.
Dwarfs are expert armourers, both as creators and wearers. They have the skills to fashion it and the sturdy frames to bear its weight.
At a Clan's request, Field Engineers are sent by their Guild, attached to artillery to ensure increased rates of fire.
Automated assembly lines increase production but also safeguard quality, according to the Guilds anyway.
These courageous warriors have fought and survived countless underground battles.
It is the Dawi's solemn obligation to protect the deeps of their Karaks.
With the aid of Runesmiths, new armoured suits have been developed to withstand high temperatures, as well as enemy strikes.
Dwarfs excel at artillery placement and creating bulwarks and trenches for their defence.
Not just any beardling can operate war machines, so the Engineers' Guild ensures only approved crew operate its instruments.
As both honour and sworn duty, the Hammerers are the royal guard, accompanying Lord or King into battle.
To read aloud from the Hold's Book of Grudges is to enrage all Dawi and bring them to battle.
Combining runes of lifting with heavy armour plate increases protection without compromising a 'copter's ability to fly!
Innovations in engine mechanics means faster 'copters. Even now, many aircraft are being retro-fitted with improved engines.
A Slayer's wrath is not something enemies wish to see - they do not fear death, they crave it!
Those that have taken the Slayer Oath must seek their doom in combat to appease an earlier shame.
When the Runepriests enter a Karak, they will stop at the Shrine of Grimnir, granting his favour to any who wish it.
Regulating pressure is an important aspect of many Dwarf devices. New, self-releasing valves heighten such performance.
Swordplay is not merely a craft but an art form, taught to the Empire’s officers by the greatest Tilean swordsmiths.
The ship of state must have a pilot of some skill if stormy waters are to be avoided.
The greatest minds of the Old World are gathered by the Empire’s various institutions to impart their knowledge and methods of efficiency.
Usually sporting impressive facial hair, barking orders, and instilling discipline, every regiment needs a decent sergeant.
As regiments gain renown, their standards become talismans that are just as important as their sword-arms.
A regimental musician beats out a regular tattoo to aid marching, even speeding units along when the meter quickens.
A ready supply of fresh, professional soldiers isn't always possible, so drafting in irregulars can keep numbers up.
An army can only march as far as its supplies will last. Wagons loaded with goods allow for larger forces.
Missile units that train together excel at firing a deadly hail, so not all members of the regiment have to see the target.
Industrialised production of ammunition for handguns has allowed the Empire to hoard large supplies.
Veteran gunsmiths work at their great inventions, racing their peers to create the largest artillery pieces.
The discovery of barrel-rifling led to increases in speed and accuracy. Both Dwarfs and men claim credit for this invention.
Veteran Gunners are able to spot a target with unerring accuracy - they've probably survived the odd misfire too…
The Imperial Architects are an eccentric bunch who have always had, well, let's say 'fanciful' ideas about how a building should look…
Packing a wallop when they strike, artillery crews are also measured on their firing rates; the faster the better.
As the fishing fleet leaves port, a prayer is said to Manann in the hope that he will provide a generous bounty.
The merchant fleets travel far and wide, collecting wares from Ulthuan, Ind and Far Cathay.
Charting the seas has always been a perilous venture. For confirmation, just ask Admiral Roth's father…
State Troops are often issued with armour plate to ensure unit cohesion and a modest level of protection.
Although the cost falls to each individual soldier, it is expected that all will use standardised equipment.
Light Cavalry need to be mobile, so shun full-plate armour. Regardless, some protection is still required.
Refined ore techniques create stronger steel, making for more durable blades and heavier weapon heads.
The secrets to forging full-plate armour are passed down to chosen smiths under the patronage of the Knightly Orders.
There are eight Steam Tanks left in the world, of which only a few have been 'improved' with thicker armour plate.
The young nobles of the Pistolkorps are called to war, many eager to prove their worth in battle!
Selective breeding allows the Empire to have good supply of steeds, capable of carrying heavily-armoured Knights into battle.
Musicians on horseback help co-ordinate charges with a siren blast of the horn, ensuring a wall of hooves and lance approaches the foe!
Taken from the Inner Circle, Preceptors are veterans and champions of the Knightly brotherhood.
The Reiksguard are the personal army of the Emperor, the standard they carry a symbol of his military might.
The Knights of the Inner Circle are the elite of the elite, amongst the best fighting men of the Empire.
The Holy Order of the Templars of Sigmar - or Witch Hunters - can be sent under an Arch Lector's order to purge vile cults.
The Grand Theogonist himself has judged this region and declared it pure and free from fell taint.
When the Dark Powers gather, the Cult of Sigmar sends its champions to rid the realm of its taint.
Some gobbos are blessed by the Green Godz to create "worky bitz".
Docile or older boars are used to pull big carts that can be piled high with shiny stuff following a raid.
The looming presence of a gnarled and muscular Orc amongst the Goblin mobs helps keep discipline and the gobbos focused on "wot matters".
Even the thickest of gobbos can operate a war machine if it has a big enough lever for their scrawny hands to pull.
Orcs like things that are bigga, so they "pimp" their chariots with large wheelz!
Orcs like a bit of 'Eavy Metal, especially on their chariots - not only is it good for defence, it also gives them something to paint on…
Greenskins have always loved to put spiky bitz on their stuff, because they like things to be as stabby as possible.
Goblin devices rely on "springy stuff" for power, and there is none better than cured Troll intestines.
Before you can operate a Doom Diver catapult, you need "willing" volunteers to be shot into oblivion. Fortunately, there's rarely of shortage of nutters.
Greenskins have embraced wearable technology by strapping on bits of metal to form crude armour - or even wings!
Worship of the many-eyed god - the Feaster from Beyond, as it is known to the Forest Goblins - ensures its children stay in the fight.
Some say it’s an art, others a science. Mostly, it’s just blind luck if you stay upright and alive.
The sharper the spear tip, the nastier the hole a gobbo can make in his enemy.
Copying the designs from stinky Elves, gobbos noticed that slimmer, sharper arrer 'eads could punch through enemy armour more easily.
Boar breedin' is more than just a spectator sport, the aim being to produce even tougher mounts.
Even Greenskins have realised that getting fast wolves to mate produces even speedier beasts!
Bigga clubs make for betta bashing.
Black Orcs can't stand the cowardice rife in other Greenskins, should they witness it they bellow out threats to keep the others in line.
It's true. Red Onez do go fasta!
Orcs like to make their chariots as tough as possible - although if they're too heavy even boars struggle to pull 'em!
Orcs like a big choppa, they like the feel of it in their hands and the weight of the hefty weapon as it pulverises the foe!
Goblins copied the bowstrings of other races, twisting the twine and even combining it with sinew.
Fanatics with longa chains have a larger arc of death - bad news for any unfortunates caught up in the loon's lethal cyclone!
Greenskins begrudgingly see the logic of barding their mounts, but it's not an easy thing to do considering what they ride to battle on!
Taking spider eggs and broodlings from nests in the forests is a deadly undertaking, but can create more vicious mounts.
In the deepest, webbed lairs lurk the Arachnaroks, now lured to battle by the Forest Goblins.
Flung into the air by a ramshackle catapult, the Doom Diver lands on the enemy in a flurry of Squig-leather wings and squishy body parts!
The Goblins steal ideas as much as anything else - they saw the deadly catapults of the Dwarfs and knew they needed a larger stone thrower of their own.
A wagon for keepin’ the Boss’ stuff in stops the more unscrupulous among da boyz from nickin’ it for themselves.
For centuries, this tome of beasts has been required reading for Necromancers who wish ultimate control, training and mastery of the dread creatures that lurk by the graveside.
The darker and more haunted the forests become, the better the habitat for fell creatures.
To become Master of Swarms is to dominate each creature within the flock, so they sway to his control.
Contained in this passage of De Noirot's tome are methods of usurping the alpha beast of the pack.
When Vargheists emerge from their tomb-like cocoons, they have a great hunger - this cantrip ensures it never slakes.
There are words of power to control Vampires that have been lost to the bestial side hidden within them.
Beasts that are already blooded, that know the thrill of hunting living things, will always be the superior breed.
A fresh supply of meat or at least knowledge of where to find it, usually some poor Sylvanian hamlet, keeps these beasts pliant.
A Terrorgheist feeds by terrifying its prey into paralysis, this invocation invigorates the monster further.
A text of powerful binding and one of the nine Books of Nagash. It contains countless rituals to ensnare wrathful spirits, summon ghoulish creatures and imbue such fell things with dread power.
Ushoran was the first Ghoul King; his spirit can be invoked with the right words, and his children summoned.
Bestial chants around fell markings, eating their own, ghoulish kind.
Using a litany from a language not spoken for generations, the speaker can bind malevolent spirits to his cause.
This incantation quickens the pace of the hordes over great distances. Forever marching, never tiring.
The book implants racial memories of Mourkain, Ushoran and Kadon to haunt the creatures' waking dreams.
Behold the reapers - summoned from their cairns to enact the doom of all mortals!
The enemy should fear the war engines of the dead, as screaming skulls fly over the ramparts!
To enshrine an Ancient Lord of the Horde is to show the mortals just how fragile their own petty lives are.
Shackling Wraiths via arcane means keeps their spirits tethered longer to the mortal plane.
Said to be transcribed from scrolls of Neferata herself, this grave codex instructs recently-sired Vampires in the art of infiltrating, influencing and spreading the Vampiric curse across the world.
Fear is a great motivator. The living within the captured settlement must appease their new lord.
The Vampires' baleful rituals are enacted to ensure the spread of Undeath.
As the industry of Undeath grows, so do the dwellings of its Dark Lords. It is blood that drives this dread economy.
Witching Night is the best time for ritual sacrifice, for evil gods are awaiting such gifts at year's turn.
The tenets of Lahmia encourage Vampires to inveigle themselves into the mortal populace.
Defeated mortal Knights who fought valiantly are, on occasion, granted the Blood Kiss.
Some Vampires are masters of disguise, using their charm and magic to infiltrate powerful organisations and noble houses.
As a Vampire grows in dark majesty, others of evil intent will flock to this master, for they also crave power.
Returning to the sanctuary of his Black Coach, the Vampire will begin the Lahmian art of rebirth.
As its dark empire rots, the Midnight Aristocracy clings to pride and the fineries of nobility ever more strongly.
The Book of Blood contains indexes and lexiconic keys for deciphering ancient manuscripts said to hold true power.
Pulling all the strings, his puppets are willing tools, ready to be used at their master's command.
The darkest chapters within these pages are the incantations of Nagash, rituals that only the most powerful Vampires dare attempt.
Also known as the Tome of Bone, this dread volume, authored by Arkhan the Black, is filled with his secrets for instilling vigour and other deathly abilities into zombified and skeletal vessels.
A single-word boon, spoken during the ritual, will harden the skin of corpses as they jerk back to life.
To raise the ragged banners above the legions can be taxing, for they may have been enchanted by other sorcerers.
Blessed be the ties that bind, for they shall last forever.
The coming of death isn't necessarily a disadvantage, and can even prove the most special of boons.
Contained within, the secrets of holding together - quite literally - a rotting horde of Zombies.
Speaking this Dark Magic mantra will bring forth yet more skeletal remains.
There's no way a man without a mind should be able to wield a weapon effectively, but he can, with supernatural help.
The armour many soldiers are buried with is brought back to the surface - a gift from the grave.
Guided by Arkhan's text, the Necromancer enters the barrows he plunders, invoking ancient curses as he goes.
Summoning long-lost warriors to join your shambling dead boosts the yearning hordes' capable champions.
A small cantrip can locate ancient blades upon an ancient battlefield long thought lost to time.
The dread animator can wake the most stubborn of ancient warriors from their deathly slumber.
